thread.title: How *not* to recruit for a mod

post.author: whatthe
post.body:
Well the general consensus is to lay out some guidelines about what you need to do when recruiting or making public a mod idea and seeing as der_ton already posted some info on this in the modJOBs section here it is for those that haven't seen it. Whilst you don't need to follow these guidelines to the latter you do need to at least consideration them *before* posting any form of 'recruitment advert' for team members, failure to do so will just lead to a 5 page ridicule fest and your mod will go nowhere fast.

This is what you *should* do
der_ton wrote:
I think we should have some basic guidelines (not as rules to be enforced, but hints) on how to recruit members for a mod. It just saddens me to see these 2 sentence postings where someone is asking for talented people to dedicate their time to a mod that he obviously doesn't have a clear picture of yet, and where it's unclear if it was just a spontaneous idea or has ripened over some days atleast.
Maybe these hints are worth a sticky in this subforum.
Some ideas for such a sticky:
- try to impress people with your idea, show them that your mod is something special
- post screenshots or concept arts if you have any
- post a story
- post something about yourself: previous work, your age (I consider that really important), where you get your inspiration from
- post some basic project schedule/workload estimations
- try to use understandable english in your post. Typos are not really catastrophical, but they WILL make your post look unpolished and your request won't be taken as serious as it would otherwise. You want to attract people, not show them your incompetence.


---------------------------------------------------------------------------

the following is unfortunately typical of inexperienced modders who may have great ideas but simply don't understand what needs to be done in order to express those 'great' ideas to others in order to gain their support and interest (and respect to a certain extent). Read the following 5 pages to get an idea of the typical responce you'll get to this type of *basic* approach and learn from it if you're thinking of posting a recruitment advert. People *need* as much info as they can get.

This is what you *shouldn't* do
whatthe wrote:
original topic title
"me make mod and need help"

Hi, I am currently working on a script for a doom 3 mod and I need help (DUH!) Firstly I need someone to create a logo for my mod, if you would like to make the logo, do it, and send it to hamatt@optusnet.com.au I also need some to create and host the website. I also need a modeller and a skinner. If you wish to join either one of, or both, send us some images or video to show that you are good. By the way, dont send me stuff from you yahoo or stuff like that, only send me stuff from normal everyday email accounts.


---------------------------------------------------------------------------

To requote a single line from the above to drive the point home...
Quote:
You want to attract people, not show them your incompetence

post.author: Sir Random
post.body:
whatthe,
You can't honestly expect guys who have spent months/years learning how to map/model/code to just join up with you, when you have nothing but a dream in your head.
Thousands of people would love to make mods, but only a small percentage actually take the time to learn what's involved in mapping etc. Then, an even smaller percentage will go on to actually finish a mod project.

If you want guys to take you seriously, then at least spend a few weeks learning to use the doom editor and make some maps to show people what you have in mind. Then you'll have something tangible to show that you are serious, and you'll have a better idea of what can and can't be achieved with the doom engine.

post.author: Gazado
post.body:
on a serious note.

All of what you have listed here so far only goes against what you are trying to do because you havnt thought about what it is exactly that you ARE trying to do.

The reason people believed that those images were you trying to say you did them yourself was due to the nature in which they were posted and the context that the thread had lead through too.

Before anyone will come join your modification, you will need to do the following things:

1) Make youself a website
2) Create a design document detailing what the mod is about and what sets it out from all the countless other mods out there
3) Show the work you have done yourself to get others interested

Those three key things will show to the public that you are serious about the task you are trying to acomplish.

You should not have made a thread requesting help without thinking out more of what you actually want to acomplish with the project.

The reason everyone is ridiculing you is because the way it seems that each time someone says something constructive, you get defensive, then answer back with something even more rediculous than what has already been stated previously.

Do some organisation work of your own, show what you are able to bring to the table for all to see, then with that, people will come and help.

Go to the "mod wanted" forum and read up in a few of those threads to see more about how things are done around here.

Finally, as its an open forum, you cant dictate to people what they say or think or if they read this thread. By the topic alone you are drawing people in - then everyone reads through what has been said already, laughs - then posts their thoughts. If you want control over your own forum go and get a free one , like from bearkey or somewhere.

Well the general consensus is to lay out some guidelines about what you need to do when recruiting or making public a mod idea and seeing as der_ton already posted some info on this in the modJOBs section here it is for those that haven't seen it. Whilst you don't need to follow these guidelines to the latter you do need to at least consideration them *before* posting any form of 'recruitment advert' for team members, failure to do so will just lead to a 5 page ridicule fest and your mod will go nowhere fast.

This is what you *should* do
der_ton wrote:
I think we should have some basic guidelines (not as rules to be enforced, but hints) on how to recruit members for a mod. It just saddens me to see these 2 sentence postings where someone is asking for talented people to dedicate their time to a mod that he obviously doesn't have a clear picture of yet, and where it's unclear if it was just a spontaneous idea or has ripened over some days atleast.
Maybe these hints are worth a sticky in this subforum.
Some ideas for such a sticky:
- try to impress people with your idea, show them that your mod is something special
- post screenshots or concept arts if you have any
- post a story
- post something about yourself: previous work, your age (I consider that really important), where you get your inspiration from
- post some basic project schedule/workload estimations
- try to use understandable english in your post. Typos are not really catastrophical, but they WILL make your post look unpolished and your request won't be taken as serious as it would otherwise. You want to attract people, not show them your incompetence.


---------------------------------------------------------------------------

the following is unfortunately typical of inexperienced modders who may have great ideas but simply don't understand what needs to be done in order to express those 'great' ideas to others in order to gain their support and interest (and respect to a certain extent). post.author: dojoteef
post.body:
I don't think he needs 5 to 10 years, but he definitely needs to take it more seriously and start doing work on his own. Heck, Ken Silverman started work on the Build Engine while he was only 17. That's the engine that was used for Duke Nukem 3D, Blood, and a number of other games. Heck he released the game Ken's Labyrinth, a Wolfenstein 3D clone published by Epic, when he was only 17.

So it is possible to do things when you are young. You just have to have dedication and the will to learn on your own. You can't expect to get spoonfed the skills required to make a game or mod. You have to actively strive for it.
